SENT.plain: In myeloproliferative disorders, aggravation of splenomegaly was reported as an adverse effect of erythropoietin (EPO)
Recently, we experienced the adverse effect of EPO in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
A 65-year-old male was admitted to our hospital for scrutiny of pancytopenia in July 8, 1991
He was diagnosed as having MDS (refractory anemia: RA)
After discharge, daily subcutaneous administration of EPO (3,000U) was started on August 1 because his Hb concentration had decreased to 9.2 g/dl
After the daily dose of EPO was increased up to 6,000U in August 15, left hypochondralgia gradually developed
His splenomegaly was aggravated from 2 finger breadths below the left costal margin before EPO administration to 4.5 finger breadths
Bone marrow examination revealed a change to extremely hypercellular marrow from slightly hypocellular marrow before EPO administration
The peripheral blood cell count was not altered
We concluded that he was a rare case of MDS in which aggravation of splenomegaly was observed, probably as a result of extramedullary hematopoiesis induced by administration of EPO
